children.name: foot a1
children.definition: foot the part of your body that you stand on and walk on :
examples: my foot hurts.
left footmy left foot ached a bit.
right foothe has broken a bone in his right foot.
front foot(= of an animal )the tiger has five claws in each of its front feet.
back/hind foot(= of an animal )the horse lifted its back foot.
big/smallhe had small neat feet.
bare(= without any socks or shoes )the marble floor felt cold under his bare feet.
flat(= having a medical condition in which someone’s feet rest flat on the ground, with no curved part )we’ve both got slightly flat feet.
booted/sandalled feet(= wearing boots or sandals )he put down his rucksack and stretched out his booted feet.
injure/ hurt your footsimon injured his foot while playing rugby.
sb’s foot hurtsshe complained that her foot was hurting.
raise/lift your feethe raised his foot off the floor and rested it on a chair.
drag your feet(= walk slowly in an unwilling way )i was dragging my feet because i didn’t want to get there.
wipe your feet(= wipe your shoes on a mat to remove dirt )be sure to wipe your feet before coming into the house.
stamp your feet(= bang them noisily on the ground )he stamped his feet in an attempt to keep warm.
tap your feet(= bang them gently on the ground )she was tapping her feet in time with the music.
shuffle your feet(= make small movements with them, because you are nervous or impatient )ken shuffled his feet and looked down at the floor.
a foot injuryhe suffered a foot injury during the match against sporting lisbon.
a foot massagewould you like a foot massage?
at sb’s feet(= on the ground, near your feet )the dog was sitting at his master’s feet.
in your stockinged/ stocking feet(= not wearing shoes )she stood 5ft 6 inches tall in her stockinged feet.
my feet are killing meinformal(= my feet are hurting )
-footed[suffix] with feet of the stated type or number
our four-footed friends (=animals having four feet)
flat-footed players/ bare-footed children (= children wearing no shoes)

children.name: hand a1
children.definition: hand the part of your body at the end of your arm, including your fingers and thumb, that you use to hold , move, touch and feel things:
examples: in her hand was a tattered old photograph.
sb’s right/ left hand
she held the book in her right hand.
sb’s free hand(the hand sb is not already using )
amy was stroking the dog with her free hand.
a gloved hand(covered with a glove)
he stretched out a gloved hand.
an outstretched hand(stretched out towards sb or sth)
she took her father's outstretched hand and began to walk from the room.
sb’s cupped hand(= in the shape of a cup )
hamil shook the dice in his cupped hand.
wave your hand
marta waved a hand to attract his attention.
clap your hands
they were singing and clapping their hands.
wash your hands
go wash your hands before dinner.
hold hands (with sb)
joanne and kevin held hands on the sofa.
shake sb’s hand(alsoshake hands with sb)
‘nice to meet you,’ he said, as they shook hands.
take sb’s hand(= hold someone’s hand )
he reached across the table and took her hand in his.
take sb by the hand(hold someone’s hand in order to take them somewhere )
she took the boy by the hand and led him across the street.
join hands(= take hold of the hands of people on either side of you )they stood in a circle and joined hands.
clasp your hands(= hold them together tightly )emily clasped her hands together and stood there nervously.
fold your hands(= put your hands together and rest them on something )lily folded both hands on her stomach.
raise your hand(alsoput your hand up) (= lift your hand, especially when you want to ask or answer a question )if you know the answer, raise your hand.
sb’s hands shake/ tremblehis hands trembled as he lifted the cup.
sb’s hand holds sthhis other hand was holding his mobile phone.
sb’s hand touches sthdaniel's hand touched mine.
sb’s hand grips sth(= hold something firmly )her hands gripped the steering wheel very tightly.
sb’s hand grabs/grasps sth(= take and hold something firmly )he felt connor's hand grasp his shoulder.
sb’s hand tightensher hand tightened on the knife handle.
a hand movementthe disease means she has trouble controlling her hand movements.
a hand gesture/signal(= a movement of your hand to show what you mean )he made a rude hand gesture at the other driver.
in sb’s handhe had a suitcase in his hand.
on your hands and knees(= in a crawling position )they got down on their hands and knees to search.
the palm of your hand(= the inside surface of your hand )the phone could fit into the palm of his hand.
the back of your hand(= the outside surface of your hand )let a dog sniff the back of your hand, rather than your fingers.
with your bare hands(= without using a tool, weapon, machine etc )with his bare hands he forced the doors apart.

children.name: toe a2
children.definition: toe one of the five movable parts at the end of your foot: ngón chân
examples: hestubbedhistoe(= hurt it by kicking it against something )on a rock.
little/big toe(the smallest or largest of your toes )
your big toe/ your little toe
-toed[suffix] having toes as described
the two-toed sloth

children.name: heel b2
children.definition: heel the rounded back part of the foot:gót chân
examples: the heel of your foot(= the curved back part of your foot )
he kicked his opponent with the heel of his foot.

children.name: sole x
children.definition: sole the bottom surface of your foot, especially the part you walk or stand on :lòng bàn chân
examples: the sole of your foot
the soles of her feet were aching from the long walk.
thesoles ofhisfeetwere caked in mud.

children.name: instep x
children.definition: instep the raised part of your foot between your toes and your ankle :mu bàn chân
examples: the instep of your foot
open your stance slightly, play the ball back - opposite the instep of your right foot - and make a steep, aggressive swing.

children.name: fist c2
children.definition: fist a hand with the fingers and thumb held tightly in. people close their hand in a fist when they are angry or are going to hit someone : nắm tay; quả đấm
examples: she held the money tightly in her fist.
sheclenchedher fists.
protestors wereshakingtheir fists at the soldiers.
malcolmclenchedhisfist(= held his fist very tightly closed )angrily.
dooley stood up andshookhisfistin her face.
varney slammed his fist down onto the table so hard the dishes jumped.

children.name: manual b2
children.definition: manualdone with the hands : làm bằng tay, thủ công
examples: the manual sorting of letters
she tried to cure the pain in my knee by putting manual pressure on the joint.
it would take too long to do a manual search of all the data.

children.name: nail b2
children.definition: nail your nails are the hard smooth layers on the ends of your fingers and toes : móng
examples: he still had dirt under his nails.
finger nail/ fingernail/toe nail/ toenail[more specific]
she had small hands with polished finger nails.
his toenails were long and dirty.
long/ short/ dirty/ clean
her long nails were painted a pearly pink.
how did you get such dirty nails?
cut your nails
you should cut your nails more often!
trim your nails(cut a small amount off )
his nails were neatly trimmed.
file your nails
a girl was filing her nails on the bus.
bite your nails
eddie bit his nails nervously.
paint/ polish/ varnish your nails(to put coloured liquid on your nails)
don't paint short nails in dark colours.
manicure your nails(to make your nails look attractive by cutting them and making the skin around them neat)
she had manicured nails and expensive clothes.
do your nailsinformal(= to cut or paint your nails )
she sat at her desk, doing her nails.
break a nail(= to accidentally damage a nail on one of your fingers )
oh, no, i've broken a nail.

children.name: quick x
children.definition: quick the sensitive flesh under your fingernails and toenails : thịt mềm
examples: he's bitten his nailsto thequick.
hernailswerebitten to the quick.

children.name: ball x
children.definition: ball the ball of your foot or thumb is the rounded part where the toes join the foot and the thumb joins the hand.
examples: the ball of your hand/ foot(= the rounded part of your foot at the base of the toes )
he has a blister on the ball of his foot.

children.name: ingrowing x
children.definition: ingrowing(us usuallyingrown) growing into the flesh :mọc vào trong
examples: she's having an operation on an ingrowingtoenail.

children.name: ring finger x
children.definition: ring finger the finger nearest to your little finger . in many western cultures, people often wear a ring on their ring finger to show that they are married or are planning to get married. : ngón áp út

children.name: thumb b1
children.definition: thumb the short thick finger on the side of your hand which makes it possible to hold and pick things up easily : ngón tay cái
examples: a baby sucking its thumb

children.name: middle finger x
children.definition: middle finger the longest finger on the hand : ngón tay giữa (kế ngón trỏ và ngónáp út)

children.name: little finger x
children.definition: little finger/ pinkie the smallest finger on each hand : ngón tay út
examples: a pinkie ring

children.name: forefinger x
children.definition: forefinger/index finger the finger next to the thumb : ngón tay trỏ

children.name: ability to use a particular hand or both hands
ambidextrous x
children.definition: ambidextrous able to use both hands equally well: thuận cả hai tay
examples: few of us are naturally ambidextrous

children.name: left-handed x
children.definition: left-handed using your left hand to write and do most things : thuận tay trái
examples: are you left-handed?
a left-handed bowler
left-hander[ c ] sb who uses their left hand to write and do most things

children.name: right-handed x
children.definition: right-handed using your right hand to write with and do most things: thuận tay phải
examples: she's right-handed.
right-hander[ c ] informal sb who uses their right hand for writing and for doing most things

children.name: fingerprint x
children.definition: fingerprint/ fingermark the pattern of curved lines on the end of a finger orthumb,which is different in every person, or a mark left by this pattern : dấu vân tay
examples: his fingerprints were all over the gun.
his fingerprints were all over the gun.
the police havetakenfingerprints from every man in the neighbourhood.
he was careful not toleaveanyfingerprints.
the police questioned beresford andtookhisfingerprints(= made a record of them ).

children.name: knuckle c2
children.definition: knuckle one of the joints in the hand where your fingers bend, especially where your fingers join on to the main part of your hand : khớp đốt ngón tay
examples: her knuckles whitened as she gripped the gun.

children.name: palm c2
children.definition: palm the inside part of your hand from your wrist to the base of your fingers : lòng bàn tay
examples: this tiny device fits intothepalmofyourhand.
in sb’s palm
she looked at the coins in her palm.
he held the pebblein the palm of his hand.

children.name: finger a2
children.definition: finger any of the long thin separate parts of the hand, especially those which are not thumbs : ngón tay
examples: we ate with our fingers.
run your fingers through/over/along etc something
she ran her fingers through his hair.
-fingered[suffix]with or using the stated number of fingers
two-fingered typing

children.name: fingertip x
children.definition: fingertip the end of a finger : đầu ngón tay
examples: use your fingertips to gently flatten the pastry.
